workshop.name: Motion diagram and graph activity - too ambitious
workshop.intro: This is to get you used to doing workshops during class.  Normally in a workshop you will be given a problem to work on in a group.  This one isn't exactly a problem.  It is more of a quick conceptual activity because I am not sure that we (your or I) are comfortable enough with this to try doing  it with a more involved problem.  In your groups you will discuss the activity and complete it.  Every one of you will make your own submissions.  Then you will be given some submissions by other people to mark.
workshop.instructauthors:
Consider the following situation:

A car starts from rest and moves to the right, speeding up.  Then it slows down to a stop.  It then immediately reverses and moves to the left while speeding up.

Sketch a motion diagram showing this motion.

When you have finished making both of these sketches, take a picture of your paper with the scanner app on your phone.  Upload the pdf as your submission.

The origin of the coordinate axes is at the starting location of the car, as shown.  Sketch an x vs. t graph for the car during the described motion.
workshop.instructreviewers: You will assess several (probably two) submissions by other people.  Follow the marking  guide.  The marking guide should be detailed enough that you won't have to use much judgement.  Before you are given the submissions by other students to assess you will given a sample submission that I made which you will be asked to assess as practice in the assessment process.
workshop.conclusion:
Thanks for participating in this activity.  Note that you will have received two marks.  One mark will be for your group's submission.  The other mark is for the quality of feedback you gave to the submissions you were asked to assess.  The grade for the quality of assessment is found by comparing your assessment with the assessments of others who marked the same submission.  If you all agree on the grade then you get a perfect mark for your assessment.

However, because this activity was still mostly to help you get used to this sort of in-class activity, the mark you get in it won't matter.  You will simply get a 1/1 participation mark for doing the activity.  I will manually upload those marks to the moodle gradebook once I've looked over the activity.

workshopform_accumulative_dimension.description:
The submission should include a motion diagram that looks roughly like this:

The  first part of it should show speeding up, like this:

The key point is that the dots should be getting farther apart in this first part.

Did they include a motion diagram which starts with dots getting farther apart?

The next part of the motion diagram should show slowing down.  In other words the dots should be  getting closer together, like this:

Did the next part of their motion diagram show slowing down by having the dots get closer together?

Now they need to show the car reversing direction.  When we show this in a motion diagram we displace the return trip so that the reverse part isn't drawn over top of the previous part, which would be hard to read.  So they should show the next part displaced.  It could be displaced up, like this:

or it could be displaced down, like this:

I have labelled  the duplicated  point where the car reverses "same point".  Don't  be picky about this.  If they didn't put this label on they should still get full marks.

Finally, they should have the return part of the trip.  I'm going to draw them all displaced down.  If they drew them displaced up that's fine.  They need to have shown the car speeding up after reversing.  But the question says nothing about the rate of speeding up after reversing.  So it could be the  same as the rate of slowing down before reversing, in which case it would look like this:

or it could be speeding up at a lower rate after reversing, in which case it would look like this:

or they might show it speeding up at a higher rate after reversing, something like this:

The point is that as  long as they show it speeding up after reversing that's fine.  How quickly it speeds up doesn't matter.

Did they show it speeding  up after reversing?

They should have also included an x vs. t graph.  It should look roughly like this:

Since the car started at x = 0 (the origin was at the initial location of the car) the value of x at t = 0 should be zero.  In other words, the curve should start from the intersection of the axes.

Does their curve start from the intersection of the axes?

The graph should contain three segments.  The first segment slopes upward, and has an increasing slope, like this:

Another description of this is that it is "concave up".  The slope at the start should be zero, but don't be picky about this.  As long as they have a curve that bends upward like this at the start of their graph give it full marks.

The next segment should continue to increase, but should have a decreasing slope.  So it should look like this:

Another description of this is that it is "concave down".  Strictly speaking the transition between these two segments should be smooth, like this:

not "kinked" like this   

But don't be picky about this.  As long as the second segment is still increasing, but with a  decreasing slope it should get full marks.
